awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Reactive Additive Manufacturing of Advanced Superalloys for Turbine Engines
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project will address the lack of high application temperature materials available for additive manufacturing. Additive manufacturing, often called 3D printing, provides increased design freedom and complex features such as part consolidation and conformal cooling channels. The performance and efficiency of gas turbines and other applications can be increased by combining design improvements enabled by additive manufacturing with a suitable high temperature material. Unfortunately, existing materials either do not have sufficient high temperature performance or are not compatible with high quality printing methods. This project will develop new nickel superalloy composite additive manufacturing materials for use with high temperature gas turbine components. Successful completion of this project will result in more efficient turbines to reduce energy costs, transportation costs, and carbon emissions. The manufacturing, power generation, and aerospace industries are expected to be impacted from this project. In addition, history has demonstrated that new materials and manufacturing technologies often lead to additional unexpected innovations. This project will help the country lead in the innovation of high performance materials technology to address the needs of the $86 billion gas turbine market and to grow advanced manufacturing jobs in the US.



This project will utilize innovative reactive additive manufacturing materials technology to develop 3D printable advanced high temperature superalloys. During additive fabrication, high melting temperature product phases will be synthesized in-situ within a superalloy matrix to significantly improve high temperature performance and improve printability. This innovative reactive additive manufacturing technology has been shown to be applicable to a wide range of materials systems including nickel superalloys in an NSF Phase I project. Metal matrix composites produced using this technology have demonstrated greatly increased strength, wear resistance, and high temperature performance relative to comparable traditional alloys. In addition, this technology has demonstrated the ability to eliminate micro and macro cracking problems with alloys that had previously been considered unprintable. This project aims to further develop one or more high temperature superalloys compatible with laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing for use in the hot sections of gas turbines. The scope of the project includes theoretical and experimental development and evaluation of novel material feedstocks, additive manufacturing processing conditions, and heat treatments. Evaluation of printed components will include measurement of density, hardness, standard and high temperature tensile properties, creep, and microstructure and phase analysis. Turbine components will be additively fabricated for pilot studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
SBIR Award Number:      1758865

Name of Company:           Elementum 3D Inc.

Company Address:           400 Young Ct. Erie, CO 80516

Telephone Number:          720-545-9016

As a direct result of the funding received under the SBIR grant, three materials were fully developed by supplementing base powders with Elementum 3D’s patented RAM additives. After testing and iterating upon nine RAM doped alloys, IN625-RAM2, IN718-RAM2, and NiR80-RAM1 were selected to receive commercial deployment due to their increased mechanical properties and printability when RAM was added. Ni247-RAM2 has a prerelease data sheet and is in the process of being finalized for commercial sale and use. Nickel alloy C276-ODS_RAM synthesized Al2O3 dispersions have shown promising results. Microcracking has been one of the leading issues during previous research attempts at making these alloys printable via laser powder bed fusion. The RAM additives have overcome that hurdle while also surpassing many physical qualities seen in pure, wrought forms.

Nickel alloys stand out as one of the most mature sets of 3D printable metals today and within nickel alloys, about 90 percent of what is 3D printed today would be categorized as a nickel superalloy. Nickel superalloys are considered the most widely used materials for applications operating in high temperatures environments, making them attractive to a wide customer base.

Promotion of the nickel superalloy product line focuses on the following attributes: improved stiffness, strength, hardness, thermal stability, high cycle fatigue resistance, wear resistance, and high temperature properties relative to comparable alloys currently available for additive manufacturing.

Key target audience includes the commercial aerospace industry and organizations that produce gas turbine engine parts, space vehicle components, automotive components, oil and gas, and power generation systems.

The fundamental understanding gained in RAM processing has also accelerated the growth of RAM aluminum alloy development. The broader perspective of RAM’s effects on mechanical qualities and grain refinement fast tracked the selection and development of Elementum 3D’s two newest aluminum materials, A7050-RAM2 and A7075-RAM2. The aluminum 7050 alloy with RAM additives has already been purchased and vigorously tested by outside companies with excellent results. The gold medal prize for the Advanced Manufacturing Olympics Materials Hurdles challenge, hosted by the US Air Force Rapid Sustainment Office, was awarded to A7050-RAM2 for its superb performance in the competition.

Elementum 3D’s RAM technology has made it possible to introduce a variety of advanced AM metal alloys with unmatched properties. This effort combined computational materials design with extensive experimental materials and process testing and development. Over the past five years Elementum 3D has positioned itself in the marketplace as the AM materials expert and will further solidify its position through the promotion of their recently developed RAM nickel superalloy product line, which have improved properties and printability compared to existing products.


Last Modified: 08/08/2022
Modified by: Jacob S Nuechterlein
